awd_titl_txt: Probabilistic Modeling and Stochastic Optimization for Effective Demand Response Decision Management under Uncertainties in Emerging Smart Energy Markets
awd_abstract_narration:
With rapid expansion of renewable energy resources and residential smart home networks, power distributors in the future must respond to an extremely dynamic and complex supply-demand balancing problem, which will lead to a dramatically different energy market. To address such market transformation, the concept of demand response (DR) has been proposed to achieve dynamic supply-demand balance through customer side response of load and generation regulated by dynamic market electricity prices. Although there have been many encouraging advances in DR research, the current data analytics and optimization models are still limited in capability and scalability to achieve effective DR decision-making under various system and market uncertainties. The primary target of this project is to bridge this knowledge gap and provide new predictive modeling and optimization methods enabling effective DR decision management for load service entities (LSEs) to deploy practical and sustainable DR programs in the energy markets. The methodological breakthroughs in this project have broad societal impact on facilitating smart grid transformation in the upcoming years for large-scale integration of renewable energy resources and residential smart home networks. This project will organize outreach and educational activities to broaden a diverse student participation, particularly underrepresented minorities, in highly impactful research areas that integrate data science, statistics, machine learning, and optimization for complex system decision-making in the big data era. Results of this research will be disseminated through a series of workshops and seminars on decision analytics, probabilistic machine learning, and smart energy technologies. 

To address the challenges of deploying practical and sustainable demand response (DR) programs in a stochastic smart grid market, this research will establish new mathematical modeling and stochastic optimization methods via three integrated research tasks: 1) develop a new probabilistic deep learning method to investigate complex spatial-temporal variable interactions and make sequential forecasts with uncertainty quantification; and accordingly develop new forecasting models for key market variables, such as electricity price, load and renewable generation, etc.; 2) develop a multi-agent adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) approach for a comprehensive DR planning and operational optimization framework to achieve real-time optimal intra-day DR operations; 3) develop a two-stage optimization framework to optimize energy transactions and DR decisions in the day-ahead energy markets. The probabilistic deep learning method combines Bayesian nonparametric methods with deep learning structures to solve complex multivariate sequence-to-sequence forecasting problems. It is critical to quantify forecasting errors precisely to mitigate risks of decision making in uncertain markets. Both the multi-agent ADP and two-stage optimization problems will use a design and analysis of computer experiments approach that will enable effective real-time and day-ahead decision-making processes for an LSE to interact with dynamic customer agents and stochastic smart energy markets. The outcomes of this research will construct a solid methodological foundation to develop effective and sustainable DR management programs for the emerging smart energy markets. This project will advance the frontiers of knowledge in probabilistic deep learning and stochastic optimization research to solve many challenging real-world decision-making problems in highly stochastic environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to enhance demand response (DR) decision-making in smart energy markets by integrating machine learning-based forecasting with adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) based stochastic optimization techniques. The research outcomes have advanced theoretical foundations and provided practical tools for energy price and demand forecasting, uncertainty quantification, and real-time decision-making in highly stochastic smart energy markets with a high penetration of renewable energy.  

Intellectual Merit: This project has significantly contributed to probabilistic forecasting, uncertainty quantification, and stochastic optimization with applications to energy systems. One of the key intellectual contributions is the development of Composite QR-Transformer and GP-Transformer models for multivariate time series modeling and forecasting with uncertainty quantification. The research introduced Adaptive Conformal Residual Fitting (ACRF), a novel uncertainty quantification method that ensures coverage-guaranteed prediction intervals for multivariate time series forecasting. The developed deep learning forecasting models have been extensively evaluated for energy price and load forecasting using Texas ERCOT energy market data. The developed adaptive conformal prediction-based uncertainty quantification method demonstrated superior performance to enhance uncertainty quantification reliability, making it well-suited for the DR decision optimization under uncertainty problem.

Beyond market forecasting, the project also developed a DACE-based adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) optimization framework, which integrates probabilistic forecasts into real-time demand response decision-making. The developed stochastic optimization approach enables Load Service Entities (LSEs) to participate day-ahead and intra-day energy market with enhanced capability to make optimal decisions under uncertainties in highly dynamic energy markets. The project developed a multi-agent DR stochastic optimization model to enable LSEs to coordinate with dynamic pricing-sensitive customers and optimize operational cost and market bidding under customer behavior uncertainties. These methodological advancements were rigorously validated through large-scale computational experiments on Texas ERCOT energy market data and comprehensive simulated smart energy system scenarios, ensuring their robustness and scalability for real-world applications.

This project contributed to interdisciplinary research, workforce development, and public dissemination. The research findings have been widely disseminated through high-impact journal publications, conference presentations, and student dissertations. Two PhD students have completed their dissertations from this project, one Ph.D. dissertation focused on multivariate time series forecasting and robust uncertainty quantification, and the other Ph.D. dissertation focused on ADP-based stochastic optimization for DR decision making. Four major papers have been generated from this research on topics covering probabilistic forecasting, uncertainty quantification, stochastic optimization, and multi-agent DR decision-making. The project has also developed open-source software tools for probabilistic forecasting and demand response optimization, making the methodologies accessible for future public research and industry applications.

Broader Impacts: this project extend across multiple disciplines and sectors, including energy systems, machine learning and artificial intelligence, operations research, and public policy. The forecasting and optimization models developed in this project improve energy market variable prediction accuracy, optimizing demand-side participation in energy markets, and reducing operational costs under dynamic market uncertainties. These advancements will support policy development in areas such as renewable energy integration, smart grid management, demand and energy trading, contributing to more sustainable and resilient energy infrastructures in the future.

By bridging machine learning, stochastic modeling, and optimization, the project has fostered interdisciplinary research, which has potential to influence a wide range of fields beyond energy systems to demonstrate the scalability of the research outcomes. The developed deep learning-based multivariate times series forecasting models with accurate uncertainty quantification have broad applications in finance, climate science, healthcare analytics, agriculture, and supply chain management, where uncertainty-aware predictions play a crucial role. Similarly, the ADP-based stochastic optimization methods have broad applications in logistics, transportation, healthcare, and industrial automation.  

Additionally, the project played a crucial role in workforce development, providing advanced training to undergraduate, M.S., and Ph.D. students, as well as postdoctoral researchers in Industrial and Systems Engineering and Electrical Engineering. Through hands-on research, interdisciplinary mentorship, and structured project meetings, the research participants gained expertise in deep learning, stochastic modeling, and decision optimization, preparing them for careers in academia and industry. The project also ensured the seamless transition of research knowledge by training new research students and involving them in computational validation and research publication efforts.

The project research findings have also been integrated into graduate and undergraduate coursework at UT Arlington, enriching curricula in data science, AI, and energy analytics. By incorporating real-world demand response challenges into academic teaching, the project has stimulated student interest in complex problem-solving for energy systems and smart grids. Furthermore, research outcomes have been disseminated through technical reports, invited talks, and conference sessions, expanding public and industry engagement in the adoption of emerging AI-driven energy management system solutions.

This project has pushed the boundaries of AI-driven energy forecasting and stochastic optimization, providing scalable solutions for demand response, uncertainty quantification, and smart grid decision-making. The research outcomes will continue to drive innovations in intelligent energy management, contributing to the development of more efficient, resilient, and data-driven smart grid systems for the future.
